title: Which is More Random?
question_text: Two students are working on a project in AP Statistics. The students are taking random samples of size $n = 100$ from a population with a known mean of $\mu = 10$ . The students sample means are given below: Student Mean $1$ $\mu_1 = 9.5$ $2$ $\mu_2 = 10$ Each student is claiming their sample was "more random". Which student is correct?

choices.text: Student 1 1 - Because their mean was close to the population mean, but did not equal the population mean exactly
Student 1 1 - Because student 2 2 's mean was a whole number, which is very uncommon
Student 2 2 - Because their sample mean equaled the known population mean
Student 2 2 - Because Student 1 1 's mean was not a whole number
Both sample were equally random because different samples taken from the sample population can be different

solution:
When selecting a sample from a population, with or without a known population mean, it is important to remember that differences between the samples can exist. This idea is called sampling variability . All sample of size 100 100 will not produce the same sample mean.

Therefore, since both students took random samples of size 100 100 , both of the samples would be considered equally "random", even if one sample produced the a sample mean that was equal to the population mean.

Choice 'E' is correct.
